text: ’Tis not unknown to you, madam, I am a poor

speaker: FOOL
text: fellow.

speaker: COUNTESS
text: Well, sir.

speaker: FOOL
text: No, madam, ’tis not so well that I am poor,

speaker: FOOL
text: though many of the rich are damned. But if I may

text: have your Ladyship’s good will to go to the world,

speaker: FOOL
text: Isbel the woman and I will do as we may.

text: Wilt thou needs be a beggar?

speaker: FOOL

text: God till I have issue o’ my body, for they say bairns

speaker: FOOL
text: are blessings.

speaker: COUNTESS
text: Tell me thy reason why thou wilt marry.

text: My poor body, madam, requires it. I am driven

speaker: FOOL
text: on by the flesh, and he must needs go that the devil

speaker: FOOL
text: drives.

speaker: COUNTESS
text: Is this all your Worship’s reason?

text: Faith, madam, I have other holy reasons, such

speaker: FOOL
text: as they are.

speaker: COUNTESS
text: May the world know them?

speaker: FOOL
text: I have been, madam, a wicked creature, as you

speaker: FOOL
text: and all flesh and blood are, and indeed I do marry

speaker: FOOL
text: that I may repent.

speaker: COUNTESS
text: Thy marriage sooner than thy wickedness.

speaker: FOOL
text: I am out o’ friends, madam, and I hope to have

speaker: FOOL
text: friends for my wife’s sake.

speaker: COUNTESS
text: Such friends are thine enemies, knave.

speaker: FOOL
text: You’re shallow, madam, in great friends, for the

speaker: FOOL
text: knaves come to do that for me which I am aweary

speaker: FOOL
text: of. He that ears my land spares my team and gives

speaker: FOOL
text: me leave to in the crop; if I be his cuckold, he’s my

speaker: FOOL
text: drudge. He that comforts my wife is the cherisher

speaker: FOOL
text: of my flesh and blood; he that cherishes my flesh

speaker: FOOL
text: and blood loves my flesh and blood; he that loves

speaker: FOOL
text: my flesh and blood is my friend. Ergo, he that

speaker: FOOL
text: kisses my wife is my friend. If men could be contented

speaker: FOOL
text: to be what they are, there were no fear in

speaker: FOOL
text: marriage, for young Charbon the Puritan and old

speaker: FOOL
text: Poysam the Papist, howsome’er their hearts are

speaker: FOOL
text: severed in religion, their heads are both one; they

speaker: FOOL
text: may jowl horns together like any deer i’ th’ herd.

speaker: COUNTESS
